Posts.Content: May 20, 2009 07:27AM - edited May 20, 2009 07:29AM by idaho The fact is even if you have chemo there is no guarantee that IT won't come back.  In my case the onc. put all my stats in his little computer and told me that chemo only upped my chance of no recurrence by 4 %.  All the side effects from chemo for a 4 % chance-no thanx.  A lot of researchers are finding out that cancer is being over treated.  Just like a few years ago they  figured out that mastectomy was not mandatory breast cancer treatment.  DO get a second opinion, have him put your stats in the computer, and tell you what they are, AND take the oncotype test. Just know that chemo is not mandatory, there are a lot of different factors that play into it.  There is a thread on here called "bottle o' tamoxifen" that has a lot of good info. Tami

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2009 07:12PM - edited Apr 24, 2009 07:14PM by idaho Hi Cook1.  I started radiation a month ago.  I have not had much skin reaction, just a little pink.  You will visit with your rad oncologist once a week (or you should), if you have any skin reactions he will tell you what to do about it.  Most people don't have any reaction until 3 or 4 weeks in.  Did they give you tiny tattoos?  That is how they line you up in the machine, they use laser beams to do that.  Xrays can also show the inside of your breast (that is what a mammogram is- an xray).  They do take pics of everyone.  It helps the dosimetrist (physics doc) beable to direct the beam where you need it most.  Most docs now take pics of your face also, that way they can make sure they are matching the right treatment with the right person.  It is pretty normal to have an upset stomach after rads.  Tell you doc he can probably give you something to calm it down.  I would definitely ask you doctor AGAIN about the two traces of LCIS, maybe they think the radiation will get rid of it.  Most radiation places have co-ed changing rooms.  It is a blow to your ego and modesty, but I figure I have had worse done. (having a baby etc).  Hang in there and read all you can on these boards-(there is a thread about radiation) you will learn a ton.  Tami         Oh yeah, the  boosts usually come at the very end of treatment (like the last five days) boosts just treat the place you had your lump taken out.)

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2009 01:36PM - edited Apr 25, 2009 01:37PM by idaho I think you definitely need a second opinion, or a new Doc.  I have had core needle biopsy and fine needle aspiration.  Both were done on lumps that were deep in my breast- so core needle biopsy is NOT just for skin lesions.  Since you don't have a "visible" lump I would suggest an MRI- it is more reliable.  The way I understand it you don't have to have a lump to have IBC though- it can just be on your skin. (correct me if I am wrong)- If  you are scared of incisional biopsy (like I was- it just didn't make sense to do a surgery and then have to do ANOTHER if it was cancer!)  DEMAND a core needle biopsy.  I did and got my way. You are awake the whole time and they just numb your breast.  The Doc I was going to had never heard of that so that was a BIG clue that I needed a new GYN.  I accidentally found it on the internet.  I think the confusion is between the punch biopsy and the core needle biopsy.  Punch biopsy does only take a few layers of skin- core needle biopsy can go as deep as needed and "Grabs" a sample of tissue.  It is your breast and your choice.  Do some more research and ask lots of questions here.  Peace to you- Tami
